Well, as I say, there were 2,000
maps in the two collections

1536.61.text:
and many more maps
I found elsewhere.

1539.45.text:
And so, the challenge was to
create some kind of order.

1542.43.text:
So, I essentially created five
categories which I'm going to go

1547.29.text:
through rapidly, to give you a sense
of the breadth and the creativity

1552.40.text:
and the vitality of the
pictorial map genre.

1556.36.text:
I've mentioned Disney
and Disney, Walt Disney,

1560.93.text:
gets into the genre very early
with this Mickey Mouse map

1564.96.text:
of the United States that was
produced as a map that was folded

1568.71.text:
up in a pencil case, that was
distributed to school children

1575.07.text:
So, you can imagine the
millions of boxes of pencils

1578.61.text:
with this map rolled up and what
an extraordinary way to get Mickey

1583.75.text:
and Goofy and Donald
into children's minds.

1587.70.text:
They didn't even need
to see the cartoons.

1590.42.text:
They could just see
it on a pictorial map.

1593.63.text:
And this is just the beginnings
of Disney's involvement.

1597.37.text:
So, this is what I
call "Maps to Amuse."

1602.45.text:
The Lindgren Family of
Spokane, Washington State,

1607.64.text:
during The Depression, decided to
create smiles on people's faces

1615.08.text:
and also perhaps make a bit of
money, by creating pictorial maps

1622.20.text:
There's an example here of
Yellowstone and Jackson Hole,

1627.15.text:
and after the end of
the Second World War,

1629.38.text:
they got into the decal
market and produced --

1632.00.text:
I think they became the leading
decal manufacturer and producer.

1635.59.text: And so, we've got a decal

1637.37.text:
on the right showing
the simplification

1639.33.text: of the map on the left.

1641.35.text:
And so, if you were a tourist to
one of those great national parks,

1645.79.text:
you could pick up a decal and
put it in your car window.

1649.06.text:
And that of course was very
popular for many decades,

1654.04.text:
and perhaps collect
these decals as well.

1656.72.text:
And then, the phenomenon
of the brag map.

1662.41.text:
You've perhaps all seen that
famous New Yorker cover of the view

1666.03.text:
from Manhattan and
how the world kind

1668.01.text:
of just falls away beyond
Manhattan Island and the center

1676.17.text:
And so, showing a very
narrow view perhaps

1681.51.text:
or perspective of average
New Yorker.

1684.80.text:
Well that type of map, is not
just confined to New York City,

1689.60.text: but is found across the country

1691.90.text:
and the usual suspects here is
the Texan view and I hardly need

1697.61.text:
to say anything about it, except
Texas, as you can see protrudes

1703.58.text:
to my geographical
training is not the case.

1707.71.text:
So, we get this brag maps, being
produced to boost particular states

1712.45.text:
or cities, Los Angeles, and
Florida, New York, involved in this.

1718.07.text:
So, the various types of maps
to amuse, to create a chuckle

1723.95.text: or put a smile on someone's face.

1727.16.text:
Then there's a second category which
are maps with a didactic function.

1733.77.text:
And here is a publicity blurb
for picture history maps

1739.90.text:
from the Graphic History
Association based in New York.

1743.69.text:
And notice, designed by
Elizabeth Shirtcliff [phonetic].

1746.60.text:
She produced several
wonderful pictorial maps,

1750.54.text:
but I found almost nothing
about Elizabeth Shirtcliff.

1754.30.text:
I wish perhaps the family
might still have an archive.

1758.78.text:
One of the challenges of
this work was not only --

1762.41.text: it was one thing to find the maps.

1764.04.text:
The second thing was to find
the archives about the artists.

1767.40.text:
I had some strokes of good fortune,
but then there are other artists

1770.94.text:
such as Shirtcliff, I could
find very little about.

1774.48.text:
But she was interested
in producing maps

1780.65.text:
And so, we get this kind
of map being produced.

1783.49.text:
This is by actually an English
ex-patriot, Ernest Clegg,

1788.30.text:
who came to the United States after
the end of the First World War.

1792.96.text:
And his maps are distinguished
by a very fine calligraphy.

1797.60.text:
And this is a map produced
or published

1802.84.text:
by Washington's National Cathedral
in honor of an anniversary

1809.90.text:
if you look at, a very
splendidly designed map.

1812.59.text:
But clearly, this is
not a map to amuse.

1815.08.text:
This is a map to educate
about George Washington.

1818.89.text:
And there are a number of maps of
American presidents and great men

1823.94.text:
and women as well,
that are produced.

1826.60.text:
A map produced by another
woman, Emma Bourne, in 1940.

1834.05.text:
America: A Nation of One
People from Many Countries,

1838.57.text:
published by the Council
Against Intolerance in America.

1845.11.text:
This map, I am fortunate to have
a copy of this map, and it was put

1850.38.text:
on an exhibit at the Osher
Map Library at the University

1854.29.text:
And I was told by the
curator that this was one

1856.65.text:
of the most popular maps in the
exhibition because of course,

1859.83.text:
it resonates so much with
our present situation.

1863.27.text:
So, a map in 1940,
campaigning against any type

1868.41.text:
of intolerance here
in the United States.

1870.71.text:
So, clearly again, a map with a
very serious, didactic purpose.

1875.81.text:
And a third example, is I think one
of the great literary maps produced.

1885.39.text:
This was produced by
Edward Everett-Henry

1888.54.text:
for a printing company
in Cleveland, Ohio.

1892.52.text:
This is a map that has had a
certain amount of publicity

1896.59.text:
through the Library of
Congress's exhibition

1898.99.text:
and book a few years
ago, about literary maps.

1904.76.text:
and of course it's showing
the voyage of the Pequod

1909.91.text:
and I just love the way
Everett-Henry merges the sort

1915.10.text: of two dimensions of the map form.

1917.43.text:
So, we have the outline of the
South Atlantic and Indian Ocean

1920.46.text:
into the Pacific, as
well as the sort

1922.17.text:
of more three-dimensional imagery of
the voyage and the people involved.

1929.16.text:
So, a very powerful map and there's
a number of these that he produced

1937.27.text:
Then there are maps,
a third category

1940.60.text: of places and regions and states.

1943.71.text: And indeed, of countries as well.

1945.85.text:
And this is by a Cleveland
artist, Arthur Suki [phonetic],

1954.21.text:
Clearly, it's all about
sun, down there.

1957.42.text:
This was a map produced as a
publicity piece by the Miami Herald.

1962.18.text:
It's I think quite rare
to find and this copy is

1969.21.text:
And you get that art deco sense
of the radiant sun that he's put

1972.54.text:
in the bottom right
corner, illuminating

1977.66.text: This is a map I particularly enjoy.

1981.37.text:
And then out on the west coast,
a map by Michael Baltekal Goodman

1988.70.text:
who was at Berkeley and
this is again, a 1930's map,

1994.95.text:
showing Berkeley and Oakland
and San Francisco Bay,

1998.92.text:
and I think you can see the
various art deco tropes.

2003.04.text:
The sort of chevron
waves, the electric winds.

2007.88.text:
We often have the winds
from the four quarters shown

2012.07.text:
on Medieval maps, often
get replicated

2014.57.text:
on pictorial maps of
the 20th Century.

2016.22.text:
And you can see in the top left
that a rather electric wind there,

2021.00.text: with the sort of zig zags.

2022.81.text:
And then there's a leaping antelope
among the vegetation back here,

2029.45.text:
which is straight out
of French art deco.

2032.18.text: So, a wonderfully art deco piece.

2035.76.text:
This was actually on my first
day, looking at the Fair

2039.30.text:
and Parry collections, I had looked
at oh, probably 7 or 800 maps.

2045.78.text:
It was getting towards closing time
at 5 o'clock, and the last folder

2049.34.text: for the day was brought out.

2050.89.text: And the very last map, was this one.

2054.75.text: This is the highlight of the day.

2057.77.text: The best has been saved for last."

2059.57.text:
There's a large piece,
very colorful.

2061.75.text: Makes a tremendous impact to see it.

2064.36.text:
And I urge you to see these
as objects in themselves,

2069.94.text:
rather than digital imagery on
the web or in this presentation,

2073.38.text:
because there is a certain
physicality and visceral reaction

2077.58.text:
to them when you see
them as objects.

2080.59.text:
And then this one by Vernon
Farrow, a glorious bird's eye view

2092.95.text:
And finally, in terms of pride of
place, a number of universities,

2098.06.text:
Harvard, Cornell, and
in this case Chicago,

2100.74.text:
produced maps for their alums,
celebrating their campuses.

2105.73.text:
So, this is the University
of Chicago campus --

2111.45.text:
Then industry got into the act,
so another category is maps

2114.87.text:
for industry, and industry wants to
advertise its services and products.

2119.86.text:
So, here we have the Alaska Shipping
Company selling its passenger

2125.90.text: sailings up to Alaska from Seattle.

2129.73.text:
Notice the cartoon
strip at the bottom.

2133.42.text:
Again, a very cartoony map
done by Joe Schull [phonetic],

2136.80.text:
a western artist for
Great Northern Railway,

2140.03.text:
advertising the Great Northern
service to Glacier National Park.

2145.91.text:
I love the bears confronting
the tourists

2151.61.text:
The airlines got involved
in the act.

2155.28.text:
So, this is Pan-Am, the
great international airline,

2158.56.text:
advertising its first
routes to Latin America.

2162.11.text:
And again, we've got
humor here with the birds

2169.86.text:
in this particular piece
by Thompson [phonetic].

2172.84.text:
And then a final map for
industry is very much industrial.

2177.86.text:
This is a map done to
celebrate the opening

2180.93.text:
of the Cleveland Terminal
Building in 1929.

2183.83.text:
Some of you may know
it, if you're from Ohio.

2186.89.text:
And essentially, the story is,
"We've created this skyscraper,"

2190.36.text:
I believe at the time the
tallest outside of New York.

2193.74.text:
"Come and do your business
in Cleveland.

2196.92.text:
We are the center of
the industrial Midwest."

2200.22.text:
And area we hear a lot about
today, the so-called Rust Belt.

2205.36.text:
But here, it's in all its glory
with the steam locomotives,

2208.97.text:
electric trains, the automobiles,
the Great Lakes freighters,

2216.66.text:
So, it's a wonderful sort of
advertisement for this new,

2225.34.text:
Then we come to the
Second World War.

2228.43.text:
So, this is my fourth category,
and we have maps for war.

2233.94.text:
This is actually before
Pearl Harbor.

2235.89.text:
The United States feels secure
behind its airplanes and battleships

2240.94.text:
and so forth, but I want
to draw your attention

2243.03.text:
to this very standard
Mercator map here that is used.

2247.61.text:
But we're at the -- on the
verge of the so-called Air Age,

2252.99.text:
which is going to change
cartography.

2254.78.text:
As you can see here, classic
Air Age map, as if we're looking

2258.17.text:
from outer space, or at
least from an airplane,

2262.99.text:
This is a map by Howard
Burke [phonetic],

2265.70.text:
I think for the San
Francisco Examiner.

2269.03.text:
He also did work for the
Los Angeles newspapers.

2272.33.text: And you got a very different sense

2274.08.text:
of how the world is
shown cartographically.

2276.83.text:
We moved away from the
Mercator projection,

2279.22.text:
and we've got these
pictorial elements in it.

2282.25.text:
And then I think the sort of the
grand finale are the maps produced

2287.70.text:
by the federal government,
the U.S. Navy in particular,

2297.39.text:
When I was here, I was down in the
Navy yard, difficult to get into,

2302.39.text:
but to try and look at the archival
papers behind the production

2309.06.text:
And I think you can see that it's
really an extraordinary image.

2313.42.text:
And there was six of
these produced for the --

2315.98.text:
covering the American
war effort, globally.

2319.32.text:
And this really powerful image
of, coming across the Atlantic

2326.03.text:
and engaging with Nazi
Germany and many types

2331.31.text: And I think you can see sort

2332.61.text:
of Madison Avenue advertising behind
this almost sort of cinematic image.

2337.32.text:
And we know that George Annand was
working for the federal government

2341.68.text:
as other commercial artists, to
produce this kind of imagery as part

2346.47.text:
of the propaganda effort
by the United States.

2352.47.text:
And then my final category -- oh,
I'd like just to contrast this

2356.70.text:
to MacDonald Gill's map,
celebrating the Atlantic Charter,

2362.23.text:
the signing of the Atlantic Charter,
between Roosevelt and Churchill.

2365.79.text:
And this map gets published in 1944,
the same date as the previous map.

2371.89.text:
And I think you can see
that Gill is still working

2375.46.text:
with Mercator projection, really
a 19th Century image of empire --

2379.81.text:
British Empire of sea lanes
and shipping and so forth.

2383.62.text:
And the U.S. has moved into the Air
Age here with a very different way,

2388.38.text:
a very slick way of
presenting the world.

2392.82.text: The final category of the maps

2394.42.text:
for the post-war period is
[inaudible] a catch-all.

2397.78.text:
Essentially, the genre's running
out of steam by the 1960s,

2401.64.text:
although there is still wonderful
pictorial maps being produced

2406.23.text:
But this is the last flourish,
and here is an example

2410.10.text:
of an Air Age map using the polar
projection now which used again

2415.00.text:
by another woman, Sally DeLong
[phonetic] for a western airline.

2419.79.text:
Again, I think this is 1944, and
you can see these strange beasts

2424.06.text:
on the map that hark
back to Medieval maps.

2427.99.text:
Oil is of course essential to the

2433.17.text:
and 60s, and so here General
Drafting is producing a map,

2437.09.text: a pictorial map, of oil in America.

2439.85.text:
Just a -- probably a
freebie fold-out map,

2443.58.text: you could get at gas stations.

2445.78.text:
The tourist agencies in various
states were getting involved.

2450.45.text:
So, here we're out in California,

2456.38.text: the Los Angeles area to tourists.

2460.15.text:
A map produced from
the 50s into the 60s.

Disney is thinking about Disneyland
out in Southern California,

2470.51.text:
and to get the financial backing
from the New York bankers,

2473.70.text:
he creates this pictorial
map, shown with --

2476.69.text:
to give the bankers an idea of
what it's going to look like.

2480.62.text:
So, the power of the

2483.74.text:
And then, a succession of pictorial

2489.12.text:
This is by Sam McKim
[phonetic] who was one

2494.17.text:
Was tremendous team of
artistic talent working not just

2498.16.text:
on the cartoons and the films,

2505.07.text:
to popular culture, I
think it's all here.

2508.55.text:
And them, Time Life is

And so, we've got the
launch of Sputnik

and Cold War tension being

who was the Time Life staff

2530.04.text:
War, and then into
the 50s and early 60s.

2533.17.text:
And this is just showing the

2540.72.text:
And my final map, to sort
of summarize the genre,

2545.46.text:
comes out in 1969 and commemorates

And there are many
fun elements here,

2554.45.text:
but notice the presidents
there of Kennedy, Johnson,

2558.12.text: and Nixon, flying on the eagle.

This map was actually
produced for Merrill Lynch.

2568.00.text:
I wondered when they gave the

2571.67.text:
whether they knew what
they were getting.

2573.31.text:
But it's a very humorous
take on the moon landing.

2577.70.text:
And in a sense, picks
up on that sort

2584.20.text:
So, in a sense, getting back to map
as -- to amuse a mapper's humor.

2591.42.text:
By this point, the genre
is pretty well over.

2596.93.text:
And we're not getting the
output that we did in the 20s

2605.59.text:
But still to this day, there are
graphic artists producing pictorial

2614.73.text:
I was just down in Charleston, South
Carolina last week and produced --

2619.45.text:
found a wonderful pictorial
map produced

2622.47.text:
by a not local architectural

So, it must have been hours

2628.99.text:
So, there are still very creative

2635.06.text:
for the general public, and
seems to be still alive and well.

2647.79.text: Very happy to take some questions.

one might expect them

2668.71.text:
And I've looked at some

2677.79.text:
And I imagine that a number of these

2684.60.text:

2689.26.text:

2692.31.text: I think it's -- that's the reason.

2740.90.text:
for university campuses,

2752.67.text:
the location of the

2779.52.text:

2782.91.text:
that a copy was presented

2796.61.text:
And so, you can see all

But I think there are

who are producing these

you know, can you think

and within the space of just a

which is really a go-to

There are other serious collectors

I was actually giving a

at the Miami International Map

2868.62.text:
and the comment was, "No
one's really interested

2876.43.text:
And so, the dealers are moving

2886.32.text:
So, it is a very exciting,

>> Stephen Hornsby: I mean the
Farrow map of Manhattan from 1926,

is now going for several

and I think because
of the Chinese market,

2914.13.text:
We're still not into the kind

2918.75.text: maybe a very fine 17th Century map.

2921.07.text:
I don't collect those type of maps,
but the prices are certainly rising,

2930.23.text:
I actually put together a reasonable

2938.35.text:
Being up in Maine, I couldn't

2940.90.text:
of Congress every week to

So, I purchased some maps for my own

2960.44.text:

2964.36.text:

2969.47.text:
Yes, yes. I resisted
putting a placemat in,

2972.56.text: but maybe I should have done.

2975.30.text:
What I wanted to do with the
book, was to give the, in a sense,

2980.09.text:
the greatest highlights, as well
as a representation of the variety

2989.46.text:
So, there are maps in the book
that are relatively easy to find.

2994.11.text:
Maps produced by the oil companies,
for example, or by Disney.

2998.83.text:
These are maps that some of you may
well have kicking around at home.

3002.26.text:
So, they've got very
little intrinsic value

3005.68.text:
but they are producing and
showing a pictorial image

3011.01.text:
But I also wanted to show the
maps such as the Vernon Farrow map

3014.79.text:
of Manhattan, which
are really quite rare

3017.11.text:
and are splendid examples
of artistic endeavor.

3021.83.text:
It must have taken hours
of work to have created

3025.83.text:
that three-dimensional image of
the skyscrapers of Manhattan.

3030.76.text: So, that's what I wanted to do.

3032.20.text:
Show the -- some of the great maps
that are particularly in the Fair

3035.78.text:
and Parry collections, as well
as the everyday type of map

3039.66.text:
that you'd have in
your car or back home.

3043.60.text: So, that was the kind of criteria.

3046.81.text:
A lot of it of course, I was
dealing with 2,000 maps in the Fair

3051.41.text:
and Parry, and clearly,
I had to make a selection

3054.62.text:
and that inevitably comes
down to one's eye and interest

3058.77.text:
and what you learn about
these maps over time.

3061.77.text:
And you appreciate them
the more research you do.

3063.99.text:
You start to realize,
"Oh, this is a key map."

3066.34.text:
So, for example, the map
of Boston I showed you

3069.91.text:
that Houghton Mifflin produced,
that's about as early --

3073.74.text:
I mean there was one of New York
in 1925, but the one of Boston,

3078.46.text:
published by Houghton Mifflin,
is really almost the first map.

3082.22.text: So, that has to kind of go in.

3083.52.text:
And you've got to talk about
the Houghton Mifflin maps

3086.10.text:
and there's a number
of them in the book.

3087.71.text: And then other publishers as well.

3089.65.text:
So, there are things you've
got to sort of sort out

3091.69.text: and make part of the narrative.

3094.45.text:
>> So, you really feel that
that copied Gill and so that--

3100.24.text:
>> Stephen Hornsby: You
can see how clearly.

3102.60.text:
I mean, they're not just making
this up out of their heads.

3105.73.text:
They've looked at that
Gill Wonderground map.

3107.99.text:
But what happens is that,
although Gill might be an impetus,

3111.37.text:
there are many other influences
coming in, such as art deco.

3114.73.text:
I wouldn't say that Gill -- I mean
there are some art deco elements

3118.03.text:
in later Gill maps, but I
mean, it just takes off here

3121.30.text:
in the United States and
creates its own momentum.

3124.40.text:
And they don't need -- these
commercial artists don't need

3126.73.text:
to look to the U.K.
or to a French artist.

3133.09.text:
And this is something I
argue strongly in the book,

3136.54.text:
that this is a phenomenon
of American popular culture.

3141.30.text:
And the greatest achievements
I think,

3143.76.text: are done here in the United States.

3149.56.text:
>> Have you done any similar
research in the Asian pictorial maps

3155.64.text:
>> Stephen Hornsby: Yes,
that's a great question.

3156.94.text:
And there are certainly maps
coming up out of Japan for example.

3162.30.text: I am not an Asian specialist.

3166.20.text:
So, and I wanted to keep this
restricted to the United States.

3171.52.text:
But there certainly are
a woodblock maps coming

3175.79.text: out of Japan that I'm aware of.

3177.92.text:
And particularly associated with
the 1930s and the Second World War.

3184.11.text:
Interestingly, Muriel
Parry as I mentioned,

3187.68.text:
was a librarian at
the State Department.

3189.81.text:
And she was posted
overseas, in fact, to Japan,

3192.50.text:
after the end of the
Second World War.

3201.68.text:
almost entirely American maps,
is that Muriel Parry collected

3205.12.text:
across the globe, so there's
maps from every continent,

3211.02.text:
But maps from Africa,
Australasia, South Asia, etcetera,

3219.00.text:
And so, I got a sense looking at her
maps, probably about 900 of them,

3223.19.text:
of what other countries
were producing.

3225.46.text:
And I think if there was sort of a
great group of maps, say from Japan

3231.79.text:
or China, she would probably
have got her hands on them.

3235.48.text:
And I think there are some
Japanese maps in the collection.

3239.45.text:
And so, it was the sort
of the looking at her --

3241.78.text:
the diversity of her collection
that I began to realize

3245.69.text:
that in fact the United States
was a leader in this genre.

3261.97.text:
>> This has been a presentation
of the Library of Congress.
